tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem that requires using the torsion formula for thin-walled sections. It involves interpreting the image to determine the geometry and then applying the formula, making it a multi-step problem with a medium difficulty.

answer_validation.reasoning:
The section is an open thin-walled channel made of three flat plates of uniform thickness. For thin open sections, torsional stiffness is very low and the Saint-Venant torsion constant J is obtained by summing contributions of each wall: for a flat strip of thickness t and length l, the torsion constant is approximately $J_i = \frac{1}{3} t^3 l$. The channel has two horizontal flanges of length 300 mm and one vertical web of length 600 mm, all with thickness 2 mm. Converting to meters: $t = 0.002$ m, $l_{flange} = 0.3$ m, $l_{web} = 0.6$ m. Then
$J = \frac{1}{3} t^3 (2 l_{flange} + l_{web}) = \frac{1}{3} (0.002)^3 (2 \times 0.3 + 0.6) = \frac{1}{3} (8 \times 10^{-9})(1.2) \approx 3.2 \times 10^{-9} \text{ m}^4$.
Using the torsion relation $T = G J \frac{d\theta}{dz}$, the twist per unit length is $\frac{d\theta}{dz} = \frac{T}{GJ}$. With $T = 10$ N m, $G = 25$ GPa $= 25 \times 10^9$ N/m$^2$, and $J \approx 3.2 \times 10^{-9}$ m$^4$, we get
$\frac{d\theta}{dz} = \frac{10}{25 \times 10^9 \times 3.2 \times 10^{-9}} \approx \frac{10}{80} = 0.125$ rad/m.
This lies within the official answer range 0.12 to 0.13 rad/m, confirming the key.

step_by_step: Step 1: Recognize that the given cross-section is a thin-walled open channel (two flanges and one web) subjected to Saint-Venant torsion.
Step 2: For a thin flat strip of length l and thickness t in open-section torsion, recall the torsion constant formula $J_i = \frac{1}{3} t^3 l$ and that the total J is the sum over all strips.
Step 3: Read dimensions from the figure and convert to meters: thickness $t = 2$ mm $= 0.002$ m, flange lengths $= 300$ mm $= 0.3$ m (two of them), web length $= 600$ mm $= 0.6$ m.
Step 4: Compute the torsion constant: $J = \frac{1}{3} t^3 (2 l_{flange} + l_{web}) = \frac{1}{3} (0.002)^3 (2 \times 0.3 + 0.6)$ m$^4$.

Step 5: Evaluate numerically: $(0.002)^3 = 8 \times 10^{-9}$, total length factor $(2 \times 0.3 + 0.6) = 1.2$, so $J = \frac{1}{3} \times 8 \times 10^{-9} \times 1.2 \approx 3.2 \times 10^{-9}$ m$^4$.
Step 6: Use torsion relation $T = G J \frac{d\theta}{dz}$ to find twist per unit length: $\frac{d\theta}{dz} = \frac{T}{GJ}$.

Step 7: Substitute $T = 10$ N m, $G = 25$ GPa $= 25 \times 10^9$ N/m$^2$, and $J = 3.2 \times 10^{-9}$ m$^4$: $\frac{d\theta}{dz} = \frac{10}{25 \times 10^9 \times 3.2 \times 10^{-9}} \approx 0.125$ rad/m.
Step 8: Report the twist per unit length as approximately $0.125$ rad/m, which matches the accepted range 0.12 to 0.13 rad/m.

topic.name: Torsion of thin-walled open sections
topic.syllabus_ref: Aircraft Structures -> Torsion of thin-walled sections

concepts.name: Saint-Venant torsion of open thin-walled sections
Angle of twist per unit length

essential: Basic concept of torsion in beams and shafts
Definition and role of shear modulus G
Understanding of thin-walled open vs closed sections
Unit conversion between mm and m
Use of torsion constant J in torsion formula
helpful: Familiarity with Megson's treatment of open-section torsion
Physical intuition of warping in open sections

Main Concept: requires: Basic concept of torsion in beams and shafts
requires: Definition and role of shear modulus G
requires: Understanding of thin-walled open vs closed sections
enables: Design of stiffeners and stringers against torsion
enables: Advanced analysis including warping and constrained torsion

difficulty_factors: Requires remembering torsion constant formula for thin flat strips
Careful unit conversion from mm to m is needed
Students may confuse open-section torsion with closed thin-walled cell formulas

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.section: 3.3 and later sections on thin-walled open sections
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a thin rectangular strip in torsion, the torsion constant is given approximately by J = (1/3) b t^3, where b is the length of the strip and t its thickness.

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.chapter_title: Combined Open and Closed Section Beams
textbook_references.text_snippet: The relationship between torque, rigidity, and twist rate is T = GJ (d\theta/dL).

video_references.topic_covered: Torsional stiffness and angle of twist for circular shafts; application of T = GJ (theta/L).
Angle of twist formula and its physical interpretation.

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify open thin-walled channel -> Compute torsion constant J by summing strip contributions -> Use T = GJ (dθ/dz) to find twist per unit length.
key_insights: For thin open sections, torsional rigidity is governed by t^3, so very thin walls twist a lot.
The torsion constant of the whole section is just the sum of each wall segment's J when warping is free.
Careful unit consistency (mm to m, GPa to Pa) is essential to get a reasonable numerical answer.

formulas_principles.name: Torsion constant of thin flat strip
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to thin-walled open sections where each wall can be approximated as a flat strip of thickness t and length l; warping is free.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute torsion constant J of each wall of the channel.

formulas_principles.name: Additivity of torsion constant for open sections
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies when walls are connected in an open section and warping is not restrained.
formulas_principles.relevance: Allows combining contributions from flanges and web to get total J.

formulas_principles.name: Torsion relation for prismatic members
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies for Saint-Venant torsion of prismatic members with uniform J and G along length.
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates applied torque to twist per unit length via torsional rigidity GJ.

formulas_principles.name: Twist per unit length
formulas_principles.conditions: Derived from torsion relation for constant torque and properties.
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly used to compute required twist per unit length.

industry_examples: Design of aircraft wing ribs and fuselage frames, which often have open channel sections that must resist torsion from aerodynamic and landing loads.
Design of thin-walled beams in helicopter tail booms or control surface spars where torsional flexibility affects control response.
specific_systems: Open channel stiffeners in transport aircraft fuselage shells.
Stringers and longerons in light aircraft constructed from thin aluminum channels.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate estimation of torsional stiffness of open sections is crucial to prevent excessive twist, which can lead to control issues, structural misalignment, or fatigue failures in aerospace structures.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the closed thin-walled cell formula $T = 2 A q$ or $J = 4 A^2 / \sum (l/t)$ instead of the open-section strip formula.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They memorize one popular torsion formula for thin-walled sections and apply it blindly without checking whether the section is open or closed.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: First classify the section: if it does not form a closed loop, treat it as an open section and use strip-based J formulas.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives a much larger torsional rigidity and a twist that is far too small, sometimes off by an order of magnitude.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to convert mm to m and GPa to Pa, leading to incorrect J and twist values.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Under exam pressure, they directly substitute mm and GPa into SI-based formulas.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write all given data in SI units in a separate step before substitution; check that torque is in N m, G in N/m^2, and dimensions in m.
common_mistakes.consequence: Numerical answer can be off by factors of 10^3 to 10^9, clearly unrealistic.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using $J = \frac{1}{12} b t^3$ (bending inertia) instead of $J = \frac{1}{3} t^3 l$ for torsion.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between second moment of area for bending and torsion constant for thin strips.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that torsion constant for a thin strip has 1/3, not 1/12, and depends on t^3 times the strip length.
common_mistakes.consequence: Underestimates J by a factor of 4, giving twist four times too large.

common_mistakes.mistake: Ignoring one of the flanges and only taking the web length when computing J.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus on the longest member and forget that each wall contributes to torsional stiffness.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Explicitly list each wall segment and its length before summing J.
common_mistakes.consequence: Underestimates J, so predicted twist is too high by about a factor of 2 in this problem.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Open strip J: "One-third t-cubed times length"
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Torsion constant of a thin flat strip $J = \frac{1}{3} t^3 l$
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever you see thin-walled open sections made of flat plates.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Closed loop? Use area; Open strip? Use length.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Distinguishing formulas for closed vs open thin-walled sections
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Before starting any thin-walled torsion calculation.

flashcards.front: What is the torsion constant J for a thin flat strip of thickness t and length l in an open section?
flashcards.back: For a thin flat strip in Saint-Venant torsion, $J = \frac{1}{3} t^3 l$, where t is thickness and l is the strip length.

flashcards.front: How do you compute twist per unit length dθ/dz for a prismatic member under torque T?
flashcards.back: Use the torsion relation $T = G J \frac{d\theta}{dz}$, so $\frac{d\theta}{dz} = \frac{T}{GJ}$ for constant T, G, and J.

flashcards.front: You have a thin-walled channel section. Which torsion formula should you use: closed-cell area formula or strip-based J?
flashcards.back: For a channel (open section), use strip-based torsion constant: sum $J_i = \frac{1}{3} t^3 l_i$ for each wall. Closed-cell area formulas apply only when the walls form a closed loop.

flashcards.front: A channel has two 0.3 m flanges and a 0.6 m web, thickness 0.002 m. Compute its torsion constant J.
What does the torsional rigidity GJ represent physically?
flashcards.back: GJ is the torsional stiffness of a member: the torque required to produce a unit twist per unit length. Larger GJ means smaller twist for the same torque.

real_world_context.application: Design of aircraft fuselage frames and stiffeners made from open channel sections.
real_world_context.industry_example: In transport aircraft, thin aluminum channels are used as stringers along the fuselage. Engineers must ensure that under engine-out yaw or gust loads, torsional twist of these members stays within allowable limits.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating twist can lead to misalignment of skins and frames, causing fatigue cracking, vibration issues, or even loss of structural integrity.

real_world_context.application: Helicopter tail boom and control linkages using open-section beams.
real_world_context.industry_example: A helicopter tail boom may use channel stiffeners; if torsional stiffness is too low, tail rotor control effectiveness and vibration characteristics can be adversely affected.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect torsion analysis can compromise controllability and safety.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a direct torsion problem: quickly classify the section as open, write J = (1/3) t^3 (sum of lengths), convert units, and plug into dθ/dz = T/(GJ). It is a straightforward 1-mark question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure about the exact J formula but know that thinner walls give larger twist, estimate J using order-of-magnitude and expect a twist of order 0.1–1 rad/m, not 10^-6 or 10^3.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 2–3 minutes. Do unit conversion first to avoid rework; if stuck on the exact coefficient (1/3 vs 1/12), pick 1/3 for torsion of thin strips.

search_keywords: thin walled open section torsion channel
torsion constant J flat strip one third t cubed l
Megson aircraft structures torsion of open sections
GATE AE torsion thin walled beams
torsional rigidity GJ open channel section
warping in open thin walled beams

alternative_methods.name: Finite Element Approximation of Torsion
alternative_methods.description: Model the channel cross-section using simple beam or shell finite elements and apply a unit twist to numerically compute the resulting torque, then back-calculate J = T / (dθ/dz).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Handles complex geometries and non-uniform thickness; gives more accurate J including warping effects. Cons: Requires software, more time, and is not suitable for quick exam calculations.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful in real design work or projects where geometry is complex or where warping constraints (e.g., end plates) significantly affect torsional stiffness.

alternative_methods.name: Energy Method (Castigliano) for Torsion
alternative_methods.description: Assume a shear stress distribution in each wall, compute strain energy due to shear, and use Castigliano's theorem to relate torque to twist, deriving an effective J.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Provides deeper understanding and can be extended to non-standard sections. Cons: Algebraically intensive and overkill for simple exam problems.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: For advanced study or when deriving formulas for new cross-section shapes.

connections_to_other_subjects.Mechanics of Materials: Uses basic torsion theory, shear modulus, and strain energy concepts from strength of materials.
connections_to_other_subjects.Finite Element Methods: Torsional stiffness of open sections is often computed via FEM in real designs, connecting analytical formulas with numerical methods.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aerospace Structures: Channel sections appear in wing and fuselage structures, linking this topic to overall airframe design.
connections_to_other_subjects.Vibration: Torsional stiffness GJ influences torsional natural frequencies of beams and shafts.

deeper_dive_topics: Constrained warping torsion and warping torsion constant for open sections
Comparison of torsional stiffness between open and closed thin-walled sections
Shear center location in open thin-walled sections and its effect on coupled bending-torsion
Non-uniform torsion and warping stresses in aerospace structures

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Torsion of thin-walled sections; open and closed sections
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question nicely tests the specific formula for torsion constant of thin-walled open sections, which is explicitly mentioned in the GATE AE structures syllabus and is highly relevant to aerospace structural design.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general torsion relations (T = GJ dθ/dL) and examples for solid circular shafts, which helped confirm the use of the basic torsion formula. However, it did not directly give the torsion constant formula for thin-walled open channel sections, so the key J = (1/3) t^3 l relation was supplied from internal knowledge of standard structural formulas.

future_questions_potential: Ask for maximum shear stress distribution in the same channel section under the given torque.
Modify the section to a closed rectangular thin-walled box and compare its twist per unit length with the open channel.
Include warping restraint at the ends and ask for the additional warping torsion effects.
Ask students to locate the shear center of the channel and discuss bending-torsion coupling.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: The channel section of uniform thickness 2mm shown in the figure is subjected to a torque of 10 Nm. If it is made of a material with shear modulus of 25 GPa, the twist per unit length in radians/m is _________
